title: Parents of tragic teen tell of 'indescribable pain' at losing daughter to suicide
text:

Like thousands of freshers starting university, 19-year-old Becky Marshall had a promising life ahead.

But like so many teenagers now, she also had her vulnerabilities.

Her worried parents Stephen and Jeannette had desperately tried to get her help for her mental health issues before she left the security of her home to start out in the big wide world.

But troubled Becky had to wait months in vain for an in-depth appointment before beginning her art degree in September 2017.

In that time she had even been sectioned for 24 hours after a suicide attempt in July.

And only weeks after moving into halls at London’s Goldsmiths University, she killed herself in her room.

The coroner at Becky’s inquest blasted “many missed opportunities” that could have saved her.

And today Becky’s parents are begging the Government to introduce a scheme for mental health teams to track vulnerable students when they leave home.

Their call comes amid a growing crisis which sees around 95 students a year commit suicide – one every four days.

Becky’s dad, a policeman, said: “Tens of thousands of students are starting university right now and we must do more to protect them.

“Mental health services are the Cinderella of the NHS and things have to change. We don’t want to see any other family live through what we have.

“Losing Becky has been indescribable. We live with guilt every day that we let her go to university, but we would have crushed her dreams if we hadn’t.

“There has to be checks, balances, follow-ups and communication between students’ home NHS trust and the trust they are with at university. We need to stop failing vulnerable students who can feel isolated and lonely.”

Becky’s issues first emerged in 2010 when she began self-harming – and she was given private and NHS counselling over the years.

She started seeing mental health nurse Inderjit Randhawa in her home town Maidstone, Kent, in 2017.

But she felt anti-depressants she was prescribed weren’t working.

In July that year, she made her attempted suicide and was temporarily sectioned – yet it was still not enough to bring forward an in-depth appointment to get a diagnosis and possible medication.

Becky was still on the waiting list when she left home.

Her nurse Randhawa told the inquest her full review appointment had been downgraded from urgent to routine, saying: “She had a supportive family and seemed excited, if nervous, about going to university.”

When Becky went to Goldsmiths she got a GP appointment and saw the mental health team at the South London and Maudsley Trust in mid-October.

But she was told she still had to wait more than a month for a full review. She killed herself two weeks later. The night before her death, she sent her dad a text saying she loved him, her mum Jeanette, 57, and sister Katy, now 17.

When Stephen, 59, was unable to contact Becky the next night he drove to the university and asked staff to open her door.

(Image: Vetta)

She had left a note about her love for her family.

“That night will never leave my memory,” says Stephen.

Assistant Southwark Coroner Briony Ballard called on the trusts involved to take action to prevent similar tragedies.

South London and Maudsley NHS Trust said it had “identified areas” to improve information sharing”.

Kent and Medway NHS Social Care Partnership Trust said an internal investigation into “what should have been better care” for Becky meant “we are now working much more closely with the student wellbeing and support services with an emphasis on fast tracking students to the mental health help and support they need”.
description: EXCLUSIVE: A coroner blasted 'many missed opportunities' to save Becky Marshall's life and her family say we must help students who feel so isolated
